Tracie 07 Nov 2004, 06:48

Until this morning I felt as though I was the only unique eyeglass wearer in the world. I am 29 years old and received eyeglasses in college for reading,which I wore sometimes while studying. they were not very strong.Last month while at work I noticed I was having real bad headaches and could not read the the numbers on some MRI's I was viewing. So I went in for an eye exam. The exam seemed to take a long time, first the distance part where he tried different lenses , I didn't know I had a problem in the distance. Then he had a chart on a rod that he slid in front of me to read and I had problems with that part of it. he clicked until it was all clear,. Then the bad news he told me that I was farsighted and needed bifocals to see up close. I was upset about the bifocals, asking if i couls do without them and he told me that if I had the reading part in single vision glasses that I would not be able to see far away.

So I left with a prescription that reads R+.50 L + .75

add for reading R& L + 2.00

My husband told to get the kind without the lines so that no one would know

but the doctor told me to get the kind with the lines they would be best.

So, can I get the no line kind, would the eyeglass place do that? Im not old enough to need bifocals and I don't want any one to know, or must I have the lined bifocal . I need to return to the eyedoc for check up later. Also do I need to wear them all the time, I was so shocked about the needing bifocals at 29 that I did not ask? What should I do?

Thanks

Tracie

Val 06 Nov 2004, 13:31

John, I understand that you got new contacts. So, another solution to the problem would be to buy some cheap readers to use over the contacts when you will do intensive close work. That will release the strain. The glasses can be +1D or +1.5D (like the prescription).

--WWW-- 06 Nov 2004, 10:43

John,

One thing you could look into is a 2nd single vision pair for intensive close work - You could have it made up to the sum of the close part of the prescription:

L: -4.00 -0.75 165

R: -4.50 -1.00 162

This would be a much cheaper option than what the bifocals would cost.

Your distance vision wouldn't be that good with them, but intermediate and close pould probably be ok,so you might find yourself wearing them most of the time at work.

Julian 05 Nov 2004, 23:04

John: the main thing is that you are myopic: as you say you can't see a thing without correction. The astigmatism isn't too bad; as for the bifocal add, if you were surprised you need it you can't need it all that badly - but don't be surprised if you find before long that your arms are too short when you try to read the paper or a book. That will be time to have the bifocal Rx made up. What about the boys? How old are they? Are they short sighted like you?

Love and kisses, Jules.

John  05 Nov 2004, 20:59

I just found this site by accident. I just went to the eye doctor this week with my three sons. My oldest already had glasses and the younger two were prescribed glasses for the first time. I also had my eyes checked for the first time in 5 years. To my surprise the doctor told me that I needed bifocals and I am only 35. He told me that it was not uncommon - but still. Because of the expense of buying 3 pairs of glasses for the boys, I put off filling my own prescription. My previous prescription was

L: 5.50 -0.50 016 R: 5.75 -0.75 169

The new script is:

L:-5.50 -0.75 165 add 1.50 R: -6.00 -1.00 162 Add 1.50

I don't really know what the numbers mean except I can see a thing without glasses or contacts. From reading other posts I assume that the 2nd and 3rd numbers mean that I have astingmatism and I don't know what that means. Is it strong or weak? After going over options with the doctor filling - most of them seem rather costly. From those of you who have a bifocal script - does the 1.5 addition make that much of a difference or should I put it off for a few more years and make do with glasses that I currently have. I did get new contacts - but I wear my glasses most of the time except for social occasions.

mattp 05 Nov 2004, 05:46

JB--

My distance and astigmatism correction is similar to yours, but my add is significantly higher (+2.50). Anyway, about a year ago, I got prisms for the first time (like yours, 2D, but base in). Based on my experience, whoever told you contacts may be out is right. Once I got used to the prisms, whenever I have my glasses off I see double and my eyes turn out. No more contacts for me--I'm not even comfortable going from the bedrooom to the bathroom without my glasses anymore!

Good luck--Matt

JB 03 Nov 2004, 08:55

Just got a new prescription after my arms were getting too short.

From L -4.25 -.75 R - 4.50 - 1.00 to

L - 4.50 - .75 add + 1.00 2d b/o

R - 4.75 - 1.25 add + 1.25 2d b/o

Have been told now my lenses have prisms i will struggle with my contacts and might not be able to use them.

I went for progressive lenses with an option to switch to executive bi-focals if i dont get on with them

DWV 14 Oct 2004, 00:56

F25/2.25:

You could get trifocals, but I suspect that the intermediate viewing area will seem pretty small and you won't be able to see the whole screen at once, unless you opt for one of the trifocals with specially wide intermediate segments. A cheap and effective solution is to get bifocals made up with the intermediate prescription in the main (upper) part of the lens, and the reading correction in the lower segment.

Rae Lynn 11 Oct 2004, 22:53

Off topic, but I thought I'd give everyone an update. I've been doing well with my bifocals and having no headaches, etc.

I've been wearing glasses half the time and my contacts the other half. No one really mentions anything.

Eye Tri 09 Oct 2004, 11:44

Julian - I think this is similar to what you are talking about. Because I'm a presbiopic,hyperopic triathlete I have to swim a lot, and I really don't like not being able to see when I'm in the pool. My optician made me up some goggles that have a +3 lens for the left eye and a +4 lens for the right eye. They work great! The left lens gives me good distance vision, and the right lens allows me to read my workout schedule. To put the icing on the cake, they weren't expensive (I can provide details if anyone is interested).

Julian 09 Oct 2004, 07:03

Off topic but not totally unrelated (and I've debated with myself where to post this and am not entirely sure it belongs here): A friend of mine has been mending clocks as a hobby for a while but now, having been hit by redundancy, is setting himself up to do it for profit. The other night in the pub he was showing us the glasses he has had made for the fine work. His Rx is around -4, and these specs have one lens -1.5 and the other +1.5, so can see very close with one eye and arm's length with the other. (If that doesn't make sense I've got the figures wrong.) I've heard of monovision contacts, but always understood it wouldn't work with specs. Anyway, we all tried them on and I could see moderately well with the plus lens and nothing at all with the minus.

Love and kisses, Jules.

D-W-V 09 Oct 2004, 00:44

Mik:

The most common trifocal lenses (7x28, 8x35) have quite small intermediate segments (7 or 8 mm high). If you're going to be spending much time working at the computer, you'd probably be happier with bifocals that have the intermediate prescription in the upper part of the lens and the reading prescription in the lower segment.

Seems to me to suggest that whilst there are changes hither and thither regarding your longsightedness, the astigmatism and the reading add requirement, the overall effect is more to do with your responses on the day of the test and the optician's interpretation of those responses, with perhaps a bit of an increase in one eye's effective close requirement but nothing dramatic.

As for how that translates to a CL script for the Christmas dance I don't have a clue- sorry I know that's not a lot of help, but reading posts by others it seems that it's not a straightforward conversion!

Curt 13 Sep 2004, 12:13

Willie: If you scroll further down the page you will see that Jennifer has an rx of +1.5 ou. She is wearing either half glasses or full frame glasses for computer work. The eye doc probably thought that from a convenience standpoint, Jennifer would want bifocals sometime in the future, rather than wearing half glasses all the time. Or he may have noticed she needed a slight distance correction but didn't give it to her at this point.

Willy 13 Sep 2004, 11:09

Jennifer -- I am curious as to just what your prescription is, which may help us figure out why the doctor said you may need bifocals soon. If your current prescription does not include a near add, then you should be able to adapt to wearing them for distance as well, which might make the transition to a multil-focal easier for you.

lentifan 10 Sep 2004, 15:18

Many years ago (probably more than 20) I used to travel to work by bus. As I would alight from the bus there would often be a chubby girl in her twenties with very strong plus-lensed bi-focal glasses waiting to board. You could clearly see the round-top bi-focal segments. Her brown plastic frames were not especially large for the day, and she gave the impression of having a limted field of vision that I always associate with high-plus lenses. Much moving of the head (especially when she carefully boarded the bus). Unforunately not very pretty, but her glasses always fascinated me. I now realise she was probably aphakic and really needed the bi-focals which then seemed unusual for a relatively young woman.

DWV 10 Sep 2004, 00:54

Greg: I tend to agres with you. I sure don't see that many real people under the age of 50 wearing lined bifocals (sadly). The rarity of "seen on the web" pictures of hotties in lined bifocals backs that up.

Progressive lenses are compromises. Because pupils are not pinholes, you're always looking through an area of the lens, not just a point. If the lens has a varying power over that area, then the image will be affected. It's the same reason theres a blur around the line of a bifocal that is much larger than the negligable thickness of the line itself.

test 09 Sep 2004, 20:25

this thread updating?

Nancy 07 Sep 2004, 12:53

Greg

I think that ther are more getting bifocals younger for a couple of reasons.

Anyone over -10 or +7 should have them according to my doc.

Also, the increased work in high school and college makes more people complain of eye strain, and docs have found that bifocals can help myopes because an add around +1.5 can cause less stress even as low as -5.

John S 07 Sep 2004, 07:00

I have a pair of progressives that are +1 with a 3.25 add, due to the close work I do.

They work great for me. As far as the "smoothness", if you had a pair, you would know what Greg was talking about. I would not go off on someone just because you don't understand what he was talking about. As far as a "bifocal fetish" goes, I'm sure there are people here that feel that way. I believe Greg saying that there seems to be more bifocal use, is due to more accommodation problems (computer use), and myopia progression.

I feel, the stronger add makes a progressive lens even more useful.

In my case, I can focus on from 12" to infinity. I would not trade them for a lined bifocal. BTW, I have the same prescription in a bifocal, I don't wear them.

Curt 07 Sep 2004, 06:25

Greg: I sorta agree with Rae Lynn on this...it is definitely NOT a fetish thing. Some folks prefer progressives and others traditional bifocals. Some people can never get used to the peripheral distortion that comes with progressives. As someone once said to me about progressives: "Glasses are supposed to make things clearer, not more blurry!" For some folks, even a small amount of distortion on the edges of the lens is unacceptable. Others can manage it with no problems.

Some people like red, others like blue...

Rae Lynn 06 Sep 2004, 19:44

Carrie 06 Sep 2004, 16:32

Jennifer - I'm 20 and got single vision glasses in June this year. Like you I had been having trouble reading. I had my eyes tested where I discovered that my distance vision was better with the lenses that were allowing me to easily read the near vision test card. The optician suggested wearing glasses full-time. My prescription is +2.00 left and +2.25 right. I know it's not terribly strong and probably weaker than some peoples reading glasses (and only a little bit stronger than yours, Jennifer) but I can now see everything much clearer than before.

Does anyone know if someone is prescribed + lenses while young that they are likely to eventually go full-time (if not to start with) by their mid 30s.

Melissa 04 Sep 2004, 15:24

OK, I finally went to the doctor and here is the result:

R: +1.75 -1.00 120deg add +1.50

L: +2.00 -0.75 090deg add +1.50

I had no idea how much things have gone bad. I had +2.25 (both eyes) SV glasses for quite a while and lately was having a hard time at any distance. My doctor said I should have gotten bifocals a long time ago. Anyway, I bought very good quality, very expensive! progressive lenses and have adjusted fast.

Carrie 04 Sep 2004, 04:22

Jennifer - If your optician told you to be prepared for bifocals in the near future you are probably on the verge of needing glasses for distances as well as for reading. Try looking at distances through your glasses (probably easier with the larger frames) and you will find that things are a bit blurry at first but will get clearer after a while. Being prescribed bifocals usually means the optician is recommending full-time wear. Getting used to seeing distances with your glasses now will mean you will adjust to bifocals easier.

Mark S 02 Sep 2004, 05:33

She wears contacts sometimes with plano glasses and the add. Martha is legally blind, and had one eye removed as a baby due to a tumor. Other tumor treatments affected her vision. Her glasses are +22 with a +4 executive bifocal. She and I have the same class schedule so I provide her eyes around campus.

Carrie 29 Aug 2004, 01:59

Jennifer I thought I only needed reading glasses because I could read easier when i tried on glasses that were +1 to +2. When I eventually got my eyes tested the optician recommended wearing glasses full time as the prescription improved my distance vision as well as my close vision. I think you would be better off with full frames rather than half frames as even if you don't need them full-time just yet you might do in the future so it might be a good idea to get used to looking through the full size lenses. Obviously you will need a full frame if you get a prescription for distance vision.

O.K I dont need them all the time, but now I'm used to them I tend to wear them all the time!. No one has made any negative comments about me wearing glasses, and I don't get the headaches I used to. Glasses? The're great!!

Jennifer 28 Aug 2004, 09:44

Karen X 28 Aug 2004, 02:15

JENNIFER You sound like you are a bit far/long sighted if the ready made glasses help. But you should really have a proper eye test to determine the exact prescription for you. You might find the power of the ready made glasses is actually higher than you need and you also might be able to see further with prescription glasses which will probably be easier (and look better) than looking over the top of the ready made glasses on the end of your nose. You won't necessarily need to wear prescription glasses full-time (ask the optician) but very likely just for reading & close work.

Let us know how you get on.

leelee 27 Aug 2004, 21:11

Hi Callum, Interesting description. The swim thing went away for me after a month or so, the only thing I still notice once in a while is that sometimes it can be a little hard to "nail" super cript focus on something low as I walk by. Today I actually forgot I was wearing them. I also never had any trouble with stairs - I think the very bottom edge gets a little weaker. I also do make use of all parts of the lens.

Was your add +2.50 with the bifocals? or was that the total close (with an add of +1.75)? What is your prescription now?

Callum 27 Aug 2004, 17:16

Hi everyone

This is my first post here, although I have "lurked"for some time.Anyway, I work in a petrochemical plant, where wearing safety glasses is mandatory.If anyone requires prescription glasses, they are provided F.O.C by the works safety dept in conjunction with the works appointed optician, who, prescribed my first(and last) bi-focals. Up until then, I used a S.V pair of reading glasses,(+1.75) for computer use, and nothing else. When I got the new glasses, I was horrified at the Jump between the minimal(+0.75) distance prescription, to the new +2.5

reading segment. The glasses were, quite frankly dangerous, the dividing line on the lenses played havoc with my distance perception,especially when working on high steelwork, and because of the side shields,which were like blinkers on a racehorse, and played havoc with my peripheral vision. When I was due for another eye test this summer,I asked the optician about progressives, and he prescribed them without hesitation, the result? the best vision I've had in years, yes they can make things "swim" a little, but once you are used to them, the're great, and without the sudden "jump" when looking downwards, I would recommend anyone to go for progressive lenses in the future

Callum

leelee 27 Aug 2004, 15:29

Optix, In your opinion, what is the best progressive lens in terms of having wide intermediate and close areas. This is not an area where I would strive to pay bottom dollar. How do you find Varilux & Zeiss stacking up (or are they actually the same beast?)

In terms of the "progressives are bad" climate here on ES lately, I sort of stopped giving my opinion, because I felt about as popular as a Democrat criticizing George Jr. at a millionaires luncheon when I did so. but here goes anyway: from my experience, I doubt I will ever want to switch to lined lenses. My progressives were a little hard to get used to, but I hardly notice them anymore (tho I certainly do when I don't have then on!) If I need a bigger reading area for intensive work, I'll just get a pair of SV for that.

I do worry tho, that some new users might not be giving them a chance because of the current voice here. For some of the posters, I suspect that they would really make a better choice and I understand that is much easier to adapt to whatever lens you use first.

It is too bad that progressives are so expensive. One can only hope that prices will come down as companies try to capture a larger share of the huge late baby boomer cohort (including me) that is now "coming of age".

On the other hand us hyperopes have never been so popular!

Optix 27 Aug 2004, 13:58

Hi just want to send an input to the subject bifocals vs progressives as you know bifocals are mostly 28 or 35 mm wide segment, but progressive lenses are a jungle with different qualitys from real cheap lenses with small add corridor up to finest zeiss lenses with very wide corridor also there is special compact lenses for small frames. I think many of thewm that have tried progressives and are not satisfied has

1. Got them many years ago when they not was so very good yet or

2. Got to cheap lenses without knowing about it, or being familiar of whats aviable in the market.

Also most opticians are infact real bastards and steal the money from their patients/costumers if you had any idea about how cheap a lens is you had gone real mad....

So conclusion is that there are much money to earn by selling cheap progressive lenses instead of the good one that costs 3 times more, this is not happening with ordinary bifocals or trifocals. Because there are simply no differences noticeable by comparing a cheap or expensive ordinary bifocal lens probably only remark maybe the cheap one is not possible to tint or making sunglasses off and maybe vision quality and thats real hard to judge for a normal person.

Thanx for me for this time ;-)

Hansel 27 Aug 2004, 11:07

Whilst I am conscious of some of the Eyescene "bifocals are far better than progressives" contingent, nonetheless I would note that my wife was instantly comfortable with her progressives. Where I think she was sensible initially was in listening to the optician's advice regarding frame size. She has just ordered a smaller frame size, 6 months after the first pair, to regain the "look" she likes for herself. I will be interested in how she makes out with Gradal Short lenses. There will always be those who champion one rather than another system. At the end of the day that's where personal choice comes in. Rae Lynn would seem to be moving towards the bifocal approach. Fine, but many others like the progressive idea.

As for my friend, she works mainly with young kids in a school where reading forms a large part of the day, but much of this is "over a youngster's shoulder", so isn't really "close work".

Slit 27 Aug 2004, 06:50

Hansel Well, my first advice for her is to participate in EYESCENE threads. Scrolling down LOW VISION thread, you may find CATHY's postings which may help her a lot. How old is she? What kind of a job she's engaged in?(lot of close work?) they are important things to be considered.

 25 Aug 2004, 02:27

I dunno about the clip-on idea - you've still got to carry around a case with the clip-on, right? So, you might as well get another pair of glasses as readers, or just suck it up and get those executive bifocals that you secretly desire. C'mon, flaunt that fetish!

D-W-V 24 Aug 2004, 20:53

Daffy:

about round-tops; there's 2 type of lenses that this term could be applied to:

if you mean "curved-tops", which are like flat-tops except the top line of the segment is (wait for it...) curved, the benefit is that there's much less reflection from the line. (only a small part of the line can catch the light at any time) That style of lens may be most common in Germany, judging by Zeiss's web site. It looks like quite a good compromise.

http://www.zeiss.de/de/ophtalmic/comp/home_e.nsf/0/b25092483bf836e0c1256aea004af069?OpenDocument

If you mean round segments, (where the segment is completely circular) they're almost invisible, becuase there's no ledge to catch the light. The disadvantage is that because the optical center of the segment is displaced by the radius of the segment, "image jump" when moving from the distance to near segment is more than any other type of bifocal. I get the impression that this lens style is more common in the UK. RUOK4SPECS.com offers this style of lens in two sizes.

 24 Aug 2004, 20:38

How about putting the add segment onto the clip on? Say putting a +1.5 or someting on the clip on. That way you don't need a bifocal or extra glasses. just slip them on and presto...nice readers!

Jennifer 24 Aug 2004, 08:05

I can't see clearly distantly through my glasses, hence the reason i got half-glasses. I keep them perched on my nose almost the whole day though.

Eustace 24 Aug 2004, 07:46

Thanks to several of you for the helpful informtion on magnetic clip-on sunglasses and the feasibility of trifocls in smaller rectangular frames. I am digesting all of this before my next trip to the optician.

Julian 24 Aug 2004, 00:24

Daffy: round tops have been around longer, and at one time were a lot cheaper. Don't think I've seen a pair in ages. I tried them once and they worked fine.

Jennifer: this could mean that you are a bit hyperopic; at your age pesbyopia is not likely, though there is a condition (can't remember the name) that is similar. Can you see distances clearly through your specs? It would make sense to have your eyes examined by an optometrist.

Love and kisses, Jules.

Rae Lynn 23 Aug 2004, 16:14

mattp 23 Aug 2004, 04:42

To ignorant (in the old-fashioned sense of the word, meaning not-knowing):

These terms refer to "the line". In executive style, the line goes all the way across the lens; the whole bottom is the add while the top is for distance. FT means flat top--28 means the line is 28mm across while 35 means the line is 35mm wide. FT isdistinguishable from the not very common roound top.

Ignorant 22 Aug 2004, 19:39

When you talk about FT35 or FT 28 bigocals/trifocals, what does this mean (what does the number mean) and what is the difference between these and the "executive" style referred to.

Thanks

Brian-16 19 Aug 2004, 05:51

Mattp 19 Aug 2004, 05:22

Eustace and Geoff--

I have 35 FT trifocals in a small oval frame, and I also had the bifocal line placed lower than usual. Both the optician and optometrist tried to talk me out of this small frame and the lowered add segment, but I love it. I see well and the proper segment falls naturally where I need it.

I really wanted executive style, but I was talked into the 35 FT because they said the optics weren't as good in executive style. With my 28 FT bifocals I had before the trifocals, I found the vertical line annoying. With the small frame and wide segment in the trifocals, the top line goes practically all the way across the lens and the bottom line does--no more vertical line when I look to the side.

Here's my Rx and measurements. Hope it helps in your decision:

RX is like -4.75 with a +3.50 add.

Lens height is 30mm; top is 16mm, middle is 8mm, bottom is 6mm.

Lens width is 40mm; top line is 28mm across; bottom line is 30 mm across (it goes all the way across--frame is only 30mm wide there.

Matt

Ant 19 Aug 2004, 03:10

Hi Eustace-

I have a pair of Addidas glasses that came with a sun glasses clip and which was magnetic. I found them extremely good - easy to put on and take off - but you have to be careful not to scratch or damage the plastic when you are handling them. Would certainly recommend them.

D-W-V 19 Aug 2004, 03:04

Eustace:

About putting trifocals into a narrow frame... how narrow is narrow? My frames are about 25 mm high. I don't see why a 7x28 couldn't work in this size frame - 9 mm each for reading and distance, or 8x35, split 3 ways. If you already have trifocals, why not try covering up parts of the lens with opaque tape to match the lens size of the frame you're interested in, and see what you can see.

Ree 18 Aug 2004, 22:18

Eustace

Those magnetic clip on sunglasses are gaining popularity, and are being widely advertised. The sunglasses come along with the set of frames and are not available alone. I have a seen people who have been using them for nearly 6 months and the megnetic effect hasnt worn off. I dont know about ,, how they last while swimming,, as my friend hasnt tried that,, byt they are quite expensive and wearing such expensive glasses while is not sensible I feel, instead prescription lenses in swimming goggles or sturdy plastic frames with a head band would be a better option while swimming.

Eustace read that you are very much dependent on your glasses, i am curious to know as to what is your Rx.

Eustace 18 Aug 2004, 20:23

Hector:

I guess I don't know just what you mean by a "glasses geek." I don't think wearing one's glasses while swimming is all that obsessive. I don't know what your Rx is. But some of us are very nearsighted and, for one reason or another cannot (or do not choose to) wear contact lenses. I, for one, feel very disoriented and vulnerable if I am without my glasses for even a minute. I cannot imagine going into a swimming pool or the ocean--or even a shower, for that matter--bear eyed. I don't even take my glasses off at night until after I have turned off the bedside light. I have heard of some people who actually sleep with their glasses on. That maybe is a bit obsessive. While I don't go that far, I would just feel so uncomfortable and compromised without my glasses at every waking minute.

geoff 18 Aug 2004, 20:16

I'm going for my regular eye checkup tomorrow and expect Im probably going to get another increase. Been reading some posts about the difference between FT-28 and FT-35 bifocals. Ive always had 28s but now thinking maybe I should try 35's for studying etc....any advice?

geoff 18 Aug 2004, 19:21

Eustace/Brian - I saw those magnetic clipons when I was looking at frames a while back and the thing is, they wont just attach to any metal frame - you have to get a frame that has two little magnetic "spots" in the right places where the clipons attach. In other words you have to buy frames that come with the clipons, you cant buy them separately and wear them with any frame.

Hector 18 Aug 2004, 15:51

I, for one, would wear contacts (which I do) or take my glasses off while swimming. But to wear trifocals while swimming is a bit obsessive. Oh well....

Eustace 18 Aug 2004, 09:51

Brian 16:

I have a couple of other questions for you: I am due for an exam and possibly a new Rx soon. You mentioned that you wear clip-on sunglasses when swimming. Have you seen--or have you heard any reports on--that new type of clip-on that sticks to your frames with magnets? I think they are manufactured by one of the big desinger eyewear guys--Armani, maybe. They look neat; and, what with the cost of trifocals, this would be a welcome savings, eliminating prescription sunglasses. But I am wondering if they reallly stay on--or if the magnet wears out after a while. In any event, I'm not sure that I would trust them while swimming --at least not in the ocean! Also, for swimming, do you use a "sports band" around your head--as a precaution? I usually do, even though I have cable-style ear pieces that keep my glasses very snugly on my face. Finally, my current lenses (and always in the past) have been essentially round. The new horizontal rectangular lenses are so "in" now and they are quite attractive. But my optician tells me that it would be difficult to put trifocals in this style of frame. Do you have any input advice on this? Just how much height is need in a lense to adequately accommodate trifocals?

daffy 12 Aug 2004, 16:58

Edmund and Rae Lyn...I think the difference in opinions lies in gender. Males will not be as observant (in the case of non-OO) with many things like hair colour change, new pants, new frames, new lenses, etc. Even if they do notice, they will not usually make a comment. Whereas a girls will notice the slightest change in anyone and anything! And they will say it, especially if they are your friends. So don't be too hard on yourselves.

Brian-16 12 Aug 2004, 16:37

Eustace-I also wear them in the shower and this way they get cleaned at least once a day.

For activites like swimming in the ocean I do have clip-on shades for those bright days.Thickness in inches at the temples is greatest,maybe three-eights of an inch or .4 inches and they are high index,not sure what value.Yes,high index probably would not be any benefit for your rx,probably poly-carbonate would be okay.I have strong near add for my age of +2.25.This is great for reading and tiny print most people would steer clear of or use a magnifier.My glasses are always at bedside and when the alarm goes off I literally have to hold the clock just a few inches in front of my eyes to verify the time.I started posting here when I was 16 but will be 18 this fall and last year of high school.

Eustace 12 Aug 2004, 15:53

Brian 16:

I hope that you are still doing well with your new trifocals. I have been sort of following, with interest, your postings and the progression of your prescriptions. I began with multifocals at about age 36. I didn't have all that much trouble adjusting to them at the time, but then later I switched to trifocals--mostly because of the lower cost (and I'm not particularly vain). Then I decided that I really liked the trifocals better because they give me more precision. I don't think I have ever know anyone quite so young as you with trifocals. But, hey, if they work--and it helps you see the auto dashboard and the computer screen-- more power to you! And, I'm glad that you are not self-conscious about the lines. (After all, how many people would even notice?)

I had noted your Rx, which is considerably higher than mine, which is:

Right: -3.00 + 1.25x 105

Left: -3.00 + 1.50x 100

+ 2.75 for reading lense and + 1.50 for intermediate (for both eyes)

Even with my relatively low Rx, I feel absolutely blind without my glasses; and I never take them off except to sleep. (I even wear them in the shower or when swimming!) So, I am just amazed at some of the Rx's that are posted on Eyescene! (I assume that some people must actually just have to feel around on their beside tables for their glasses when they wake up in the morning!)

Two final questions: Is your prescription high index or regular lenses. And how thick are your lenses--in either inches or millimeters? My optician says that my prescription is not strong enought to justify high index.

Eustace

Edmund 12 Aug 2004, 11:06

Rae Lynn,

That is interesting that your friends noticed. I've worn mine lots around friends, and no one has noticed it. Either that or they are not saying they are.

When I went shopping the other night, I did notice that I missed some of the intermediate vision of progrssives. When looking at things on the shelf it was either too close for the distance segment and too far for the close segment.

Rae Lynn 12 Aug 2004, 00:39

sorry to keep you all hanging. I had to work today from 11:00-4:00 so I wore my progressives. Then after work I went and got the new lenses put in. And went out to dinner with my mom and then bowling with a couple friends.

Now its 12:30 am, and I'm pretty tired, so just a few comments. They seem to be much better than the progressives as far as not having "dead space" like Edmund said.

I had no problem reading the menu and stuff at dinner and going back and forth from looking far to near. Bowling however, was a little interesting, but I'm sure it wouldn't have been any better with progressives. Besides, normally when I'd go out like that I'd have contacts in anyhow.

The two friends I was with didn't know about it. They didn't know my other lenses were bifocal, but one of them noticed tonight. And then they both said stuff, mainly just minor jokes, nothing serious. I was kind of disappointed that they could tell, because the lighting in the bowling alley wasn't that good. So I'm sure the line is somewhat obvious.

Bespectacled Professor 11 Aug 2004, 13:45

Brian-16 11 Aug 2004, 11:10

Edmund-I agree with you about the ft-35 bifocals.I have ft-35 trifocals and before that ft-35 bi-focals.I am really glad I did not have the progressives with that distortion and smaller space to read..Long live line bifocals/trifocals !!

Edmund 11 Aug 2004, 09:27

I have been a very long time lurker of this forum, but have only posted once.

Back in October of last year, I went to see the optometrist about burning in my eyes while working at the computer. The doctor prescribed an add and recommended progressive lenses.

It took a couple of weeks to get used to them. About 3 weeks ago I was in the mall, and saw a sale on bifocal lenses. So I took my old glasses in and got FT-35 put into the frames.

The major thing that shocked me comparing the FT-35 to progressive lenses was the distortion. I realized that if I am not looking directly at something with the progressives (even in the distance) it is slightly blurry.

I really enjoy the FT-35 lenses for reading. I was finding the segment on the progessives too small for lengthy reading sessions.

My prescription is:

OD -2.25 -1.00 078

OS -2.00 -1.00 080

add +1.25

I should also add that I am in my early thirties.

This site has also shown me that are many alternatives. Before I checked it out, I thought I wouldn't be able to wear contacts anymore and would be confined to glasses. However, for the last couple days I've been wearing contacts a lot, except to work when I have to read stuff a lot. I work Part time at a bookstore. Thanks everyone, and I'll let you know how it goes.

mattp 10 Aug 2004, 06:08

Mark S--

I just saw your last post about competing in the 10K race in Maine. Was it the Beach to Beacon Race? I ran in the 5 mi Peaks island race the day before. Congratulations on your finish!

So the goggles with your distance RX worked well? How come you chose goggles instead of contacts? I go the contacts route for sports. Like you, I wear trifocals, but there's no way they can give me anything but my distance RX with contacts--the prism I need for reading can't be done in contacts. The result is terrific for running--no more glasses fogging up or getting rain spattered or constantly having to be pushed up my nose. The only problem is I have a bit of difficulty making out the time on my watch without any add RX.

How come you went with only the distance RX in the goggles? Seems like they could be made into trifocals, and then you'd have great vision all around.

Matt

The result is terrific for running--no more glasses fogging up or getting rain spattered or constantly having to be pushed up my nose. The only problem is I have a bit of difficulty making out the time on my watch without any add RX.

How come you went with only the distance RX in the goggles? Seems like they could be made into trifocals, and then you'd have great vision all around.

Willy 09 Aug 2004, 07:15

Wannabe Wearer -- A few weeks ago you said you would be getting progressives for your new (first prescription). Have you done so? Rae Lynn -- From your comments, it does sound as though the lined bifocals will help you, especially for taking notes in class (looking down, up, down, up...) Another option you may want to consider is to have contacts with your distance prescription and use low-strength drugstore reading glasses as needed. May not be the best choice for classwork, but on days when you are not in class or studying you could be without glasses for the most part.

Rae Lynn 09 Aug 2004, 01:02

Just thought I'd give you an update. I've still been trying to get used to the progressives, but my doctor agreed that since I thought the best parts of the lens was the very top and very bottom that regular bifocals would be better for me. He's ordered them and they should be here on Wednesday. Hopefully I'll like them better. I still don't know what to think about the lines that people will actually be able to see :(

Penelope 08 Aug 2004, 23:06

Just a quick update on life with executive bifocals.

Have now been wearing them for a couple of weeks and am getting used to moving my eyes not my head.I have found like a lot of others posting here that when i take them off my eyes seem to be playing tug of war with each other, not a nice sensation.

I had to go back to the optician on Saturday to get the frames adjusted and mentioned this, she seems to think i may need a small amount of prism, any answers on this would be helpful.

I am going back later this week to try prism lense, will keep you updated.

Penny xx

Mark S 04 Aug 2004, 09:31

Given your prior history of wearing contact lenses, is that what you want?

6 eyes 29 Jul 2004, 13:43

Helen,

What ever is, is. Don't wory about having ditance and reading rxs. Take it from one who is highly myopic, with an astigmatisim, and diplopia (double vision.) I have three lenses per eye.

Distance Rx,RE: -6.50, cyl.+3.25, axis 95, prism 4 BI; LE: -4.75, cyl.+1.50, axi 60, prsim 4 BI. Reading Rx, same as above add +2.00 to each lens for the astigmatisim, and prisms of 5 BI in each lens.

Nancy 29 Jul 2004, 13:19

Rae Lynn:

Helen 29 Jul 2004, 12:59

Rae Lynn,

I am in my 30s, but the last time I had my eyes test (December 2004), the eye doctor said that I would need bifocals soon and put a +1 add on my prescription. I have mild myopia and need specs for distance mainly. She only gave me a single vision rx at that point, but recommended that I came back in a year.

However, earlier this year, I went back to the eyeglass place and asked if I could get the lined bifocals. To be honest, I wish that I had stopped to consider the consequences because after the 'novelty' of getting the bifocals wore off, I began to realize that I can see to read just as well without glasses and I can see this font without any problems wearing my single vision specs.

So, this Saturday, I am having another eye test at a different place. Just felt like getting another opinion. I am expecting that I will still need the distance rx, but I don't want the + add.

Wayne_D 29 Jul 2004, 08:41

Rae Lynn,

My stepdaughter was in her early 20s when the doctor told her she needed bifocals. Eventhough she is farsighted with astigmatism (+1.25 sph, +1.25x90 both eyes) he wanted her to have a bifocal add because he said she had difficulty focusing close up due to some kind of muscle problem.

Also, I'm sure you can have your prescription made up without the add. Just tell the optician you don't want the bifocal and they will probably do it. When my wife went to have her glasses made that had a bifocal add, they actually asked her if she wanted single vision or bifocals. Secondly, you could use one of the online eyeglass optical companies and when you fill out the prescription just leave out the add part. I've ordered online, and they never have called the doctor's office to confirm the prescription.

Penelope 27 Jul 2004, 23:34

Rae Lynn , i have just recently started wearing lined bifocals, i have been having trouble with a lot of head moving / eye moving but am now starting to get used to them. The biggest struggle i had was going up / down stairs, i found if you didn't keep looking through the same segment steps would disappear, i have nearly tripped a few times.

Curt, i found your and others suggestion to wear them as much as poss the best way for me, i need the distance correction all the time anyway but it is hard to train myself to move my eyes for reading and not remove my glasses.

Penny xx

Curt 27 Jul 2004, 10:13

Rae Lynn: Another trick to getting used to progressives (or regular bifocals for that matter) is to put them on your face and leave them on for about 2 weeks. Wear them even when you don't think you need to. This will help train you to move your eyes, rather than your head (a big difference from wearing single vision lenses). If you are the type of person who takes their glasses on and off a lot, or only wears them when you have to, progressives & lined bifocals will drive you nuts. But if you leave them on all the time, you will notice them less and less.

Rae Lynn 27 Jul 2004, 00:27

Thanks for all the replies! I didn't want to hear that it might take months to get used to the progressives. I guess regular distance glasses would fine to take off for reading or I might get a pair of reading glasses to use over contacts. The doctor said I could switch to lined bifocals if these didn't work.

leelee 26 Jul 2004, 17:39

Curt, you are right. Motivation is key. I really did not want the line. I didn't want to see the line and I didn't want to be seen with the line.

Another thing to add to your list of variables is also the size of your lens.

If more people reject progressives, then maybe it will motivate the manufacturer to make them better.

Can anyone explain why progressives have the narrow intermediate channel? Why can't it be wider? I find the intermediate area is handy for lots of stuff.

Curt 26 Jul 2004, 11:27

leelee: I think a persons ability to adapt to progressives has a lot to do with motivation. If you really need the specs to see and WANT to get used to them, you are more likely to do so than someone who is somewhat undecided about the issue. But I heard an interesting take on this recently: Someone stated that they hated progressives because they expect their glasses to make things clearer, not more blurry. Of course this is an oversimplification, but some people find the peripheral distortion of progressives unacceptable - they are the ones that may be happier with lined bifocals. The strength of your add also makes some difference; the stronger the add, the more distortion. Others never even notice the distoration that comes with progressives.

Lined bifocals have their own issues, namely the image jump at the segment line, but optically, they are superior to progressives because they do not exhibit peripheral distortion.

Too many people want to write off lined multifocal lenses as "old technology" and embrace progressives as "new, inovative technology". But it is really a matter of personal preference. Some like boxers, some like briefs; some like chocolate, some don't...

leelee 26 Jul 2004, 09:23

Rae Lynn,

It takes a while to get used to progressives - sometimes months.

You might want to see if what you really have is a problem with convergence. I remember a period in college where I was plagued by reading fatigue. At the time, I got tested and was not given glasses, but told to get more rest. The problem sort of went away.

About 10 years later I got another exam and was told that my eyes had a tendency to drift out (they were right - I just always thought it was normal) I was offered a course in vision therapy which helped me coordinate my eyes better as well as more comfortably wear glasses (I'm a bit farsighted), I used those glasses on & off for a dozen years until my accommodation declined to the point where I started using glasses more often. As I recall, my reading comprehension was greatly improved with the therapy.

If I were in your position (and remember, I'm not), I would probably opt for wearing my distance prescription and taking them off for reading - assuming your bit of astigmatism is not a problem - and then possibly asking them to test you for convergence issues. If your opt does not offer or test for this, you can probably seek out an exam at a School of optometry (just get ready for a really long exam!) As much as I appreciate my progressives, I don't wish I had them sooner.

leelee 26 Jul 2004, 09:07

Grant,

I've had progressives for about 8 months, and they were hard to get used to at first (you can read my blow by blow description of the process starting Dec 9, 2003.)

I am an extremely visual person and thus super demanding consumer of optical devices but overall I'm fairly satisfied and so glad to be able to just see close things without dreading an encounter with close visual material.

Now, I don't much notice I'm wearing anything but regular glasses, and they are usually perfect for the computer. At first, and still sometimes when fatigued, the width of my focused field was too narrow. But now it is usually as wide as the computer screen. It's also really nice to be able to have exactly the right focal strength for the task at hand (since the lens is variable.) I sometimes work as much as 16 hours a day on the computer, so I can speak on this. That said, I'll likely get some SV glasses for intensive close work at my next prescription change.

I find the glasses perfect for driving, and most casual activities (my friends look so defeated and apologetic when they endlessly yank out their readers, something that never happens to me!) Much better to just be able to see! The only time I find them funny is when I'm walking outside trying to look at low lying objects as I pass by.

I think those preferring lined bi & trifocals on this list are just posters who are more vocal about it at the moment. A couple of years ago, the number of people posting about how much they preferred progressives was more the norm. It seemed like those posters had previously used lined bifocals. I think it's great to see people using all types of glasses - it makes it easier for the rest of us to use whatever tool we like.

 26 Jul 2004, 05:03

Rae Lynn, could you not just read without any correction at all? Or does that still cause problems?

Julian 26 Jul 2004, 02:54

Grant: I've worn progressives for yars with no problems; other people can't cope with them at all. If it's working at the computer that worries you, you could always get a second pair of specs, single vision, computer distance. I do use a pair like that occasionally.

Love and kisses, Jules.

JJ 24 Jul 2004, 19:26

I am nearsighted (-5.00) and tried bifocal contacts at age 47. I did not care for them and switched to monovision and used that method for two years really really liked it. I have a job where I am doing close up and computer work and I could read print and see the computer screen but it does have drawbacks and I never felt comfortable reading a book with the monovision. I had to give up monovision and because of glare issues at night or else I would still be using it.

Ann 24 Jul 2004, 18:21

VUM-

My understanding of bifocal contacts is that they work basically like bifocal glasses would. The entire lens is consistant of your distance rx with the bifocal add. In other words my lens would be the minus rx with the +2.00 or whatever prescribed . Most people think unfortunately that the bifocal add has not yet been perfected in contact lenses, and alot of people have difficulty wearing them, this is why monvision is still a popular option. If bifocal contacts were perfected, or all their cracked up to being, most would opt not to use monvison lenses, (on lens for near, and one for far), because it reduces depth perception. You need to see binocularly to have depth perception. So I'm considering having the bifocal lenses made without any distance rx. just with the add. I would then of course need to wear glasses over them to see at a distance. The reverse of contacts for a myopic person who wears readers to see near. Do I make any sense at all, or am I just babbling-Anyone else, have any opinions on the subject or advice for me? - Ann

Very Unequal Mam 24 Jul 2004, 12:06

Hi Ann, with my right eye I am very close to you although I don't have the prism.

I am -.75 with a +2.50 add (I also have a very small degree of astig. which really doesn't bother me). I am 43 also.

I am a stay at home mom and have no problem going bare-eyed with readers at home. Honestly I tend to only need the distance to drive (or with plays, ballgames, stuff like that). Plain readers work well for me but I do have some difficulty with arms length or other intermediate zone tasks. I just ordered some plain bifocals with my intermediate correction at the top and near at the bottom. I am waiting to get them. I plan to use them at home and for a few occasions while I am out (e.g., at children's museums with low-placed placards).

If I were in your boat, I would probably do a distance contact and then readers at work...but there was someone who suggested as you state, having the contacts for the reading correction and then just using distance glasses as needed. I go bare-eyed a lot so I wouldn't go that route. I have considered monovision contacts and may try that next RX change.

anyway, not a lot of suggestions from me, just wanted to let you know I'm another 43 yo with same RX.

I doubt that using contacts for reading would hasten presybopia. I have found that it progressives whether I use readers a lot or not. I probably notice more of a problem if I don't use them when necessary (but that might be more of a temporary blur from eyestrain)

take care

I have had a few people remark on the lenses,

" they are a bit old fashioned "

" wow, you must be blind "

" why not get the no line ones "

I like them and they do give a great foeld of vision, much better then the type with a " D " portion which i thought looked more old fashioned and a bit ugly

Brian-16 22 Jul 2004, 18:38

Mark S.,Nancy,Matt P. As I sit here typing on the keyboard, I am enjoying the bi-focals,and the new tri-focals.Picked them up tonight -(Thursday).I even convinced my mom to let me drive home.What a view of the dashboard with all those little lights and icons staring at me during the evening as it got dark.They were very,very, clear..This is the best total correction I have had in some time.But have noticed more side distortion as the base out prism correction increased.Tri-focal height
